address.addressline1: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center

creation.date: Text converted and initial EAD encoding provided by Apex CoVantage, April 2005

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.repository: Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center.
did.abstract: Edward Dorn was born 2 April 1929 in Villa Grove, Illinois. He studied with Charles Olson at Black Mountain College and graduated in 1955. He taught at Idaho State University at Pocatello (1961-65), the University of Essex, Great Britain (1965-1970), Northeastern Illinois University at Chicago (1970-1971), Kent State University, Ohio (1973-74) and the University of Colorado (1977-1999). Mr. Dorn died in December 1999 at the age of 70.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Edward Dorn was born 2 April 1929 in Villa Grove, Illinois. He studied with Charles Olson at Black Mountain College and graduated in 1955. He taught at Idaho State University at Pocatello (1961-65), the University of Essex, Great Britain (1965-1970), Northeastern Illinois University at Chicago (1970-1971), Kent State University, Ohio (1973-74) and the University of Colorado (1977-1999).

Edward Dorn has written and published extensively. His works include: What I See in the Maximus Poems (1960), The Newly Fallen (1961), Hands Up! (1964), Geography (1965), The Shoshoneans: The People of the Basin Plateau (1966), The North Atlantic Turbine (1967), Gunslinger Book I (1968), Gunslinger Book II (1969), Twenty-four Love Songs (1969), Tree Between Two Walls (1969), Songs Set Two: A Short Count (1970), The Cycle (1971), Some Business Recently Transacted in the White World (1971), Gunslinger Book III (1972), Recollections of Gran Apacheria (1974), The Collected Poems: 1956-1974 (1975), Slinger (1975), Views (1980), Yellow Lola (1981), and Abhorrences (1990).
Mr. Dorn died in December 1999 at the age of 70.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Correspondence to Edward Dorn from 1956-1993 comprises over half of the collection. Occasional letters are sent to either Peter Michelson or Jennifer Dunbar Dorn, but they are related either to the Rolling Stock or to the Dorn family in general. Significant correspondents include Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones), Lucia Berlin, Robert Bertholf, Stan and Jane Brakhage, Gordon Brotherston, Herb Butterfield, Tom Clark, Robert Creeley, John Daley, Donald Davie, Fielding Dawson, Clayton Eshleman, Willard Fox, Allen Ginsberg, Woody Haut, Victor Hernandez Cruz, Anselm Hollo, Harry Hoogstraten, J. H. Innskeep, Ken Irby, Terry Jacobus, Joyce Johnson, Jack Kerouac, William Levy, Ellen Mann, Michael McClure, Jim McCrary, Duncan McNaughton, Peter Michelson, Ken Mikolowski, Jeffrey Miller, John Moritz, Raymond Obermayr, Simone Okamura, Charles Olson, Joel Oppenheimer, Charles Potts, Jeremy Prynne, Tom Raworth, Joe Safdie, Ed Sanders, Nicholas Sedgwick, Al Simmons, Preman Sotomayor, David Southern, Anne Waldeman, Donald Wesling, John Wieners, John Wolff, Doug Woolf, and David Young.

Extensive notes, drafts, and rewrites of Edward Dorn's poetry include Abhorrences, Book of Poems, Captain Jack's Chaps, Collected Gran Apacheria, Cosmology of Finding Your Spot, The Cycle, Geography, Gran Apacheria, Gunslinger, Hands Up!, North Atlantic Turbine, Recollections of Gran Apacheria, Songs Set Two: A Short Count, 24 Love Songs, and Yellow Lola. Similar materials exist for Edward Dorn's works of prose, including Abilene, Abilene, The Book of Daniel, Shoshoneans, Some Business Recently Transacted in the White World, Views, and What I See in the Maximus Poems. However, various published works by Edward Dorn appear to have left no drafts or revisions to examine. Personal information about Edward Dorn is found only in the correspondence or interviews—most of the published work on Edward Dorn concerns his work, not his personal life.

Edward Dorn's publications Bean News and Rolling Stock include submissions by various authors and editorial notes. Broadsides include art and published poetry, as well as announcements of book signings or poetry readings. Taped interviews and recorded poetry readings comprise the majority of the AV materials. Photographs range from family snapshots to photos for illustrations or articles. Numerous books and periodicals have been removed from the collection and can be found in Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center. Check the library catalogue (HOMER) for call numbers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection consists of correspondence sent primarily to Edward Dorn, manuscripts and publications created by Edward Dorn, other authors' publications about Edward Dorn or his work, other authors' submissions to Edward Dorn, assorted broadsides, audio-visual materials, and photographs.

Series I: Correspondence (undated, 1956-1993) is divided into Major and Minor correspondents. Correspondence found in the Major collection include five or more letters from the correspondent, or are from prominent authors in another collection. Much of the correspondence in the Major collection is undated—these letters are filed in the front of their respective folders. The Major correspondence also includes submissions of poetry and prose if accompanied by a letter from the author. Significant correspondents include Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones), Lucia Berlin, Robert Bertholf, Jane and Stan Brakhage, Gordon Brotherston, Herb Butterfield, Tom Clark, Robert Creeley, John Daley, Donald Davie, Fielding Dawson, Clayton Eshleman, Willard Fox, Allen Ginsberg, Woody Haut, Victor Hernandez Cruz, Anselm Hollo, Harry Hoogstraten, J. H. Innskeep, Ken Irby, Terry Jacobus, Joyce Johnson, Jack Kerouac, William Levy, Ellen Mann, Michael McClure, Jim McCrary, Duncan McNaughton, Peter Michelson, Ken Mikolowski, Jeffrey Miller, John Moritz, Raymond Obermayr, Simone Okamura, Charles Olson, Joel Oppenheimer, Charles Potts, Jeremy Prynne, Tom Raworth, Joe Safdie, Ed Sanders, Nicholas Sedgwick, Al Simmons, Preman Sotomayor, David Southern, Anne Waldeman, Donald Wesling, John Wieners, John Wolff, Doug Woolf, and David Young.

Minor correspondence begins with unidentified correspondents' undated letters. Known correspondents with undated letters follow. The remaining correspondence is filed alphabetically for each year with unidentified correspondents who sent dated correspondence at the end of each year.

Series II: Dorn Manuscripts (undated, 1961-1993) are arranged alphabetically by title. Large manuscripts or photographs throughout the collection are filed in the oversize boxes—boxes 28 and 29. Edward Dorn's notebooks and calendars are arranged chronologically, with undated notebooks first.
Series III: Dorn Publications (undated, 1972-1991) contains Dorn's work with Bean News and Rolling Stock and includes drafts, manuscripts, revisions, artwork, etc. grouped by issue.
Series IV: Publications About Dorn (undated, 1982) includes other authors' work about Edward Dorn or his work include interviews, articles, chapters, essays, and poetry.
Series V: Submitted Manuscripts (undated) contains submitted manuscripts without cover letters are arranged alphabetically, by author, with unidentified authors filed first.
Series VI: Broadsides (undated) filed separately for preservation purposes. An accompanying separation sheet with an item indicates items associated with a specific correspondent.
Series VII: AV Materials and Artifacts (undated) filed separately for preservation purposes. An accompanying separation sheet with an item indicates items associated with a specific correspondent.

Series VIII: Photographs (undated) filed separately for preservation purposes. An accompanying separation sheet with an item indicates items associated with a specific correspondent. Dates for photographs can only be inferred from the dates of the associated correspondence and is so noted on the separation form and not in the finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Archives & Special Collections has a substantial collection of literary materials and the papers of individuals associated with Black Mountain College. Ed Dorn materials can also be found in the following collections, also held in the Dodd Research Center: the Papers of Fielding Dawson, Charles Olson, Joel Oppenheimer, Tom Raworth, Michael Rumaker, and Ed Sanders, and in the New American Poetry Circuit Records. For detailed information on these collections please contact the curator or ask at the reference desk.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Several items have been restricted. Contact the curator for further information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from these Papers must be obtained in writing from both the University of Connecticut Libraries and the owner(s) of the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item description, #:#], Edward Dorn Papers. Archives & Special Collections at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was purchased by the University in several installments.

scopecontent.p: (Spiral bound notebook with notes and poems)
(Blue notebook with “English Poems 1966” inscribed on first page. Contains approximately 75 pages of poems)
(Maroon notebook with mimeographed poem by Charles Olson, dated Feb. 2, 1968, pasted on the inside of the front cover. Contains approximately 31 pages of holograph notes, poems, essays, etc.)
(4to. black notebook with poems and notes)
(“Love Songs 1968-1970” inscribed on first page. 8vo. blue notebook with approximately 60 pages of holograph notes)
(Red notebook with poems, pictures, notes, etc.)
(Blue notebook with notes and poems)
(8vo. red notebook with approximately 200 pages by Jennifer Dorn)
(Blue notebook with poems, notes, newspaper clippings, pictures, etc.)

(“1971 Days and Night Rept.” inscribed on first page. 8vo. notebook covered in Thor comic book wrapper with approximately 200 pages. Contains calendar of days, appointments, addresses, thoughts, poems, clippings, photographs, etc.)
(8vo. flowered cloth notebook with approximately 200 pages of poems, thoughts, drawings, photographs, etc. by Jennifer Dorn)
(Ledger size notebook with notes by Edward Dorn. Also includes poems, drawings, collages, newspaper clippings, letters, telegrams, etc.)

(“The BK I & II Notebook...A Mexico Scrapbook for Kidd and Maya” inscribed on front page. 8vo. black and white cloth notebook contains approximately 200 pages of poems, collages, newspaper clippings, telegrams, maps, flowers, photographs, etc.)
(8vo. red notebook with entries from January to June by Jennifer Dorn)
(8vo. maroon cloth notebook with approximately 100 pages)
(4to. red notebook with approximately 150 pages of holograph notes)
(Spiral bound notebook with notes and poems)
(8vo. red spiral bound notebook with approximately 100 pages of holograph notes)
(Notebook contains notes, poems, rewrites, etc.)
(Black and maroon notebook containing poems, notes, drawings, etc.)
(Black and white notebook with poems and notes.)
(4to. blue notebook with picture of Hotel Anthony Wayne pasted on front cover. Contains notes and poems)
(4to. black notebook with notes and poems)
(4to. black notebook with approximately 100 pages of notes and poems)
(4to. black notebook with notes and poems)
